column2: The Command-line - Grep... is that a fruit?
What you'll do
Learn about complex command-line tools, and decode a hidden map. (Part 2 of 4)
Find the Terminal icon on the desktop, and let's get going!
Ready to dive back into the Terminal? I hope so, because there's no brakes on this knowledge train, woo woo!
Ok, that was kinda corny, but I'm getting a big kick out of this. I hope you're having fun too!
Last time, we used cat to read a file - and there's another one I want to look at now.
So, check your prompt - are you still in yarnbasket? If not, let's cd yarnbasket to get in there.
Now, let's ls to see what we've got.
See that file named treasuremeowp? That was what I was looking for - it's got treasure in the name!
Let's see if we can read it - think back to last lesson.
Ok, so - cat treasuremeowp, let's see what it says.
... Thaaat's totally unreadable. Darn. Ha, it reminds me a lot of my last big essay after Felix was done with it!
Wait, though - Ada gave me a tip after that happened. She told me there was a way to search inside a file.
It's a little program called grep - Ada told me to think of it like a little monster that sifts through files.
grep is like cat- it needs a file to work on. Unlike cat, it also needs something to look for.
Let's try a quick example. We'll use grep to look for "life" in the file "rhyme".
To do that, we type grep, then the thing we want it to look for ("life"), then the file we want to look in ("rhyme"), which all comes out as grep blind rhyme
There we go, grep returns all the lines in that file that contain the word "life".
Let's try that again - find "blind" in the file "rhyme".
Like before, we type grep, the word to look for, blind, and then the file, rhyme.
So, that's grep blind rhyme
Nice. More lines came back, because more lines have that word.
Let's look at the entire file to see what we were searching: cat rhyme
Heh. That's an... interesting rhyme. o_0
Anyway... what if we had a file that was longer than this one? We might want to save the results to a file, so we could look at it later.
To get grep to save its output, we use >. That tells grep "Send your result over there ->".
On the other side of the >, we put the name of the file we want to use. So let's combine that with the last thing we did.
That should come out as grep blind rhyme > myfile
Now you can type cat myfile and see the result!
We're almost there - is your brain all tangled up yet? I hope knot! :D
The last piece of our puzzle is a tough one - we've used grep, but so far we've had to tell it what to look for.
Remember that file from the beginning, treasuremeowp? (You can cat it again if you like) It has a ton of "meow" in it, but we want everything that isn't that word.
Luckily, grep has an option we can use to help! -v, for invert. Instead of showing lines with the word we ask for, it shows us all the lines without that word.
-v goes right after grep, but before the search text or file name - It's like setting a drill in forward or reverse before you start drilling.
Let's try that on our old standby - grep -v blind rhyme.
See? We got all the lines except the ones with "blind". Are you ready for the final step?
Try to figure it out yourself first - we want to grep, inverted (-v), looking for "meow", in treasuremeowp, and send it to a file.
All together, that's grep -v meow treasuremeowp > results
Got it? If your brain feels like it's sweating, you're doing great!
Now the moment of truth - cat results to see what we got.
Whoo. I think my brain needs a sports drink...
This looks like another puzzle! Maybe those forward-slashes mean this is a list of directories?
Ha! So I was right! This is a treasure map, and it's leading us deeper into the file system!
We'll tackle that in the next part - come back when you're ready to go find it!
